question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$?
inference:
$3^{-1} \pmod{11}$ means finding an integer $x$ such that $3x \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$.
$3\times 4 = 12 \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$, so $3^{-1} \equiv 4 \pmod{11}$.
$5^{-1} \pmod{11}$ means finding an integer $x$ such that $5x \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$.
$5\times 9 = 45 \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$, so $5^{-1} \equiv 9 \pmod{11}$.
$7^{-1} \pmod{11}$ means finding an integer $x$ such that $7x \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$.
$7\times 8 = 56 \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$, so $7^{-1} \equiv 8 \pmod{11}$.

$3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1} \equiv 4+9+8 \equiv 21 \equiv 10 \pmod{11}$.
$(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} \equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11}$.
$10\times 10 = 100 \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$, so $10^{-1} \equiv 10 \pmod{11}$.
Thus, $a \equiv 10 \pmod{11}$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{10}$
ground_truth:
One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align*}
(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.
\end{align*} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align*}
& (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot(15+35+21)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 5^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 9\\
\equiv~ & \boxed{10} \pmod{11}
\end{align*}

inference:
We are given $3^{-1} \pmod{11}$, $5^{-1} \pmod{11}$, and $7^{-1} \pmod{11}$.
We found $3^{-1} \equiv 4 \pmod{11}$, $5^{-1} \equiv 9 \pmod{11}$, and $7^{-1} \equiv 8 \pmod{11}$.
Then
$3^{-1} + 5^{-1} + 7^{-1} \equiv 4 + 9 + 8 \equiv 21 \equiv 10 \pmod{11}$.
We want to find the inverse of $10 \pmod{11}$, which is $10^{-1}$.
We have $10 \times 10 = 100 \equiv 1 \pmod{11}$. Thus $10^{-1} \equiv 10 \pmod{11}$.
The final answer is $10$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{10}$
ground_truth:
One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align*}
(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.
\end{align*} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align*}
& (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot(15+35+21)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 5^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 9\\
\equiv~ & \boxed{10} \pmod{11}
\end{align*}
